reviewText:
Hare in the Hat.  Objective release the hare from his cage freeing him from the magician.

What a tough little puzzle game this is.  I truly enjoyed the challenge.  Everything occurs in a single room much like Please, Don't Touch Anything occurs on a single console.  A little point and click and a lot of puzzles: picture puzzles, sliders, and logic.  Excellent game.

Warning: Skipping a puzzle results in permenantly locked achievements and I will not get into the debate over the developers' personal opinion about the fact they consider skipping a puzzle cheating.  As of April 29, 2016 with the purchase of DLC Hare in the Hat: The Abyss this permenantly locked condition is released.  Reset game and try again for the achievements.

The slider picture puzzle is Hell.  But I figured it out eventually (after several hours).  I earned the SHUFFLE achievement.  HINT: Use the center top or center bottom of the puzzle, not the sides or the middle to complete.  I used the center top, and two 'diamonds'.  It was the only place I could find to reverse those last two tiles.

On April 29 2016 the DLC Hare in the Hat: The Abyss was added.  Objective: Free the hare from the confines of his underwater containment.

Not as hard as the first game and focuses solely on the mini-games and puzzles.  Still a challenge though.  Puzzles include sliders, matching, brain teasers and basic logic.

Puzzle from HELL this time is called Hungarian Rings.  Basically put the colors in the correct place in two interlocking movable rings.  I skipped it after an hour and the beginnings of  migraine.  Did not lock the achievements for the other puzzles but no achievement for that puzzle since I skipped.  I can live with that.

Recommend this add-on.  It is just as fun and challenging as the first game.
voteText: 17 of 17 people (100%) found this review helpful

reviewText:
EDIT: now that the DLC is released, you can go ahead and skip any puzzle: only the achievement for it will need a second playthrough. In other words, you're no more banned. But my opinion about how it was handled stays.

Hare in the Hat is a short yet frustrating puzzle game where you have to free the hare owned by a magician. For that, you'll have to solve puzzles, find clues and pray that you'll not throw your computer out of the window.

Why am I insisting? In reality, the puzzles aren't hard to figure. You can go by trial and errors without problems. But there is one puzzle, with swapping pieces, where you'll end up with only two pieces to switch and not managing to do so. I suppose that I uninstalled at that point the first time I've played it. Don't try to find a walkthrough, the puzzle is random.

However, the developer added achievements and trading cards, prompting me to come back and beat finally the game. The famous puzzle was a pain in the ♥♥♥ but I was very very happy when I managed to push through it without skipping. Because skipping a puzzle here is not at all recommended unless you have unlocked all the achievements safe for the skipping one.

The developer is perhaps doing what he wants with his game. But punishing players that are skipping puzzles because he's under the impression that they're cheating, with a puzzle known to give white hair to everyone (the swap one), where you just want to skip after 30 minutes - 1 hour passed on it, after frustration and that you just want to come back after unlocking the rest... I don't agree with that. Why am I saying that? Skip a level and you will never be able to unlock the rest of achievements unless you buy the future DLC/the DLC is out, I still didn't understand that. I'm quite scared now to skip a level to reach 100% achievements.

Anyway, it's a dangerous point of view to consider that people skipping are cheaters. I've skipped puzzles before after spending time on them. I don't fall under the category of people skipping everything. It's probably the biggest negative point for the game.

Another problem is the flickering of the screen that happened a lot, especially when in Steam overlay.

Otherwise, the graphics are quite colorful and amusing, the soundtrack is good though the main sound is kinda annoying (I speak about the clicking) - I suppose that's why I disabled the audio the first time.

For the price, you can go ahead if you love puzzles. I will not put a thumb down because I disagree with the developer's point of view for an achievement as the rest of the game is good. But be warned anyway.

reviewText:
Short version: 54%Hare in the Hat is a very short collection of standard puzzles with no instructions or story, and difficulty ranging from non-existent to nearly impossible. But at least it is really cheap.

Long version:Hare in the Hat is your typical few-dollar tablet game. No story, no voices, no instructions, just one scene which gives you access to a bunch of puzzles.
The minigames themselves are standard everyday brain twisters. Some are childishly easy. Others can permanently get you stuck. And none of them can be skipped.
Most of the game time is spent by either scavenging for a new item, or by solving the tougher puzzles, like the chess minigame. But if you know what to do already, it is roughly ten minutes long, or even shorter.
If you don’t mind spending a little money on some puzzles, get it, but you won’t miss anything by skipping this one.

reviewText:
Got this game as a third party purchase. It feels more like a flash game than anything else, with a short gameplay to boot (see: my hours played). As with many other reviewers, I agree that the only difficult puzzle is the swapper puzzle that involves moving tiles 90 degrees to complete a picture.  The reason why I recommend this game though, is for what it does show: promising, polished p n' c-style escape gameplay, and its enjoyability.
VALUE: 2/10
REPLAYABILITY: 3/10
FUN: 7/10
AESTHETICS: 7/10
STORY: N/A (story isn't that important here)

TL;DR: Pick it up on the cheap, and play it during a short trip or something. Mouse recommended.

reviewText:
Hare In The Hat is a short point and click adventure in which your objective is to free a bunny by solving a series of puzzles. The game consists in only one location that contains different clickable objects that trigger the mini-games. There is no story attached to it and no cut scenes. And even though the game has an ending, the fact that it is comprised of only one scene suggests that this was designed more like a demo or as a first chapter of a longer game.

The puzzles’ difficulty vary from the easy jigsaw puzzle to some really challenging ones, for example a chess variation or rotating 4 pieces puzzles. Despite the fact that some of them have a brief indication about what you're expected to do, there is no other hint option or skip button. On the other hand, having hints and skip buttons would considerably decrease the gameplay hours since 90% of the time is spent on trying to solve those difficult puzzles. I personally got stuck a couple of times and I gave up for the moment, but then I went back to the game and eventually completed it. There are no available walkthroughs at the moment online, so you can’t rely on them to save you.

I didn’t encounter any bugs while playing the game, although a lot of people are complaining about crashes.

If your idea of fun is solving challenging puzzles, then this game is definitely for you and you should buy it, especially while it is 40% discounted. But if you’d rather play it with a guide nearby, then this game might end up being quite consuming or frustrating for you.

More reviews on the Lilly's Corner Curator page

reviewText:
NOT A GOOD GAME FOR ACHIEVEMENT HUNTERS (but still possible to get 100%).

It's a very short game with about 15 puzzles (finished in ~90min). There's no indication of where to start or what to do next but that don't really matter since everything happens in one room. Just click around and see what happens.
Some puzzles are very easy and some are hard but not impossible to do. Some of the clues (click on a question mark) don't really make sense and despite knowing what to do you can still get stuck. Again, no puzzle is impossible.

This is not a good game for achievement hunters. There are currently 16 normal achievement (you get most of them by finishing puzzles) and 1 hidden achievement. The hidden one is for cheaters"
date: you can get it by skipping a puzzle but (and here's the bad thing) it will lock out your ability to get 100% if you haven't already gotten the other 16. Your ability to gain achievements again will be unlocked by buying the DLC
hoursPlayed: no. Bad. Skipping a puzzle because it's too hard or you're stuck is not cheating
voteText:
it's skipping a hard puzzle. The "developer" added it just to punish achievement hunters. Cheating is using a program to unlock achievements without really playing the game. See the difference? The "developer" don't.
EDIT: Supposedly you won't get locked out of achievement hunting ATM if you get the "cheater" achievement before the DLC arrives but I'll wait to get it until all future achievements are active/collected.

reviewText:
Public Review on behalf of the Opium Pulses Steam group
Few words about the game
Really great Point and Click game, full of puzzles and brain teasers with pleasant soundtrack in the background. Your goal as a player is to solve bunch of puzzles placed around the room to free hare that is being kept by a magician. Personally I didn't played any puzzle game in a looong time and it bringed back so many memories from childhood that I just want to play more puzzles, riddles and adventure games like this one :D

Advantages
Sounds and music is good and on point
Puzzles are fun to solve and they're not too hard, what makes it accessable for everyone to play
Fairly cheap for that ammount of content
Colorful and pleasing to eye graphics
Disadvantages
Music is a little bit buggy, stops and starts randomly from time to time
At some points if you miss anything, it's just spamming everywhere to find a clue what to do next
I really disapprove with idea of blocking off achievements and calling players cheaters if you wants to skip any puzzle. It's understandable that some people might get stuck somewhere. Also only way to unlock it is to buy DLC. Bad move
This review was possible thanks to Orlygift[www.orlygift.com]. Thank you for providing me with this key!

If you find my review helpful or funny be sure to follow Opium Pulses curator page right here for more reviewed games!

reviewText:
What a shame.
I actually liked this game. It has nice, polished graphics and vibrant colours. It has fun music. And it has both puzzles and an adventure gaming component (in that you have to explore the room and objects within, click on stuff to see what they do, use objects, etc). And from what I'd played so far, it also seemed pretty interesting.

But it also has bugs.

When I tried to skip one of the puzzles (the clown tile-swap), the skip window just kept vibrating non-stop and the game hung. I tried a total of 6 times to skip this puzzle to no avail, before giving up.

I then found out from the discussion forum that this game is quite buggy in general.

If they fixed the problems I'd give this game another go.

reviewText:
Very short game; don't buy it unless it's on sale for 40% or more.

The only reason I've logged 1.1hrs and not 0.6hrs is because of one puzzle in the game that's exceptionally frustrating; the Hare And Clown puzzle. I'll post how to do it in the Community Forums.

The puzzles are mainly all very conceptually simple, with the difficulty being in the execution, like the one I've mentioned.

If you're a hardcore puzzle fan, the type that's a fan of Braid, or the type that's waiting for Miegakure to come out, this game is likely not for you.

If you're a lot more casual when it comes to puzzles, then go ahead and buy this if you want.

Still, it's a good way to kill an hour of time, two if you've never played such a game before.

reviewText:
This is seriously the most piece of <bleep> that keeps crashing. Yes I'm this annoyed. I like the puzzles enough, but don't like it that with every click it decides it wants to stop working.

*Completes game, re-enables antivirus, which 99,99% of other games have no problems with.*
Ok back to real review.

Info for deaf and hard of hearing people:Fully Accessible. No spoken text. Not even music puzzles, which is a relief.

Cons: CRASH CRASH CRASH. Have to turn off antivirus. Amazing.
Some puzzles are asinine. Seriously. The swap puzzle must’ve been invented by a demon.
No real story. It’s just puzzle after puzzle. You solve one puzzle to be able to get an item for the next puzzle.
Peek-a-boo! Often it’s hunt and peck to see where the next puzzle is at.
Warning for 100% Achievement Hunters: First complete the whole game without even skipping any puzzle. Then you’re forced to ‘cheat’ by skipping a puzzle to get the last ‘cheater’ achievement. After this, you won’t be able to get achievements anymore.
Pros: Some puzzles are cool enough. Bit short.
Conclusion:Extremely crash-prone which almost made me want to uninstall this on the spot. Thankfully it’s a short game, but the swap puzzle is a puzzle from hell. If you can get this for extremely cheap, be my guest. Cheap as in, maybe 25 cent.

reviewText:
There is nothing wrong with the art, sound, or premise of this game, but it is extremely buggy for me.  Both on my previous and my new laptop, the game crashes every couple of minutes, making the game fairly unplayable.  There has been no official reply or feedback on the issue which several people have mentioned in the forums.  Although the game does autosave nicely, meaning no lost progress when there's a crash, the sheer frequency of crashing still makes the game frustrating and unplayable.

There is also a lack of a skip button, which would've been helpful as the game crashed repeatedly during one of the puzzles, and there was a point where I would've liked to just skip over it and progress onwards.  A skip feature is sometimes considered a cheat and not all games offer it, but where there are seriously gameplay and stability issues, it would have made it more bearable.

So all said, this game gets filed under Meh" and will not be touched again unless there is significant updating and/or bugfixing.  The game was cheap
date: so I don't feel overly cheated
recommended: but I certainly won't support this developer any more unless there's a dramatic increase in stability.  But there are also people who haven't had the same issues with it
hoursPlayed: so you could always roll the dice and see if you're one of the people that CAN play it
voteText: because it IS a good puzzle game aside from the technical errors."

reviewText:
It's cozy, it's fun, it's hard and it's entertaining.
We are talking about Hare in the hat, a puzzle game which combines hidden object and puzzles.
I have been twisting my mind for a long-long time, i completed 5 of the puzzles and realised that's it's not my cup of tea.
Though, i have been enjoying this game from the beginning till the end.

I have not much to say more since it's a quite small game.
Let's go to the ratings down below:

#### PROS ####

The music and other audio elements are really comforting, not perfect but surely great.
Brain twisting puzzles, It will take long to complete without a walkthrough believe me.
Great price tag
Very decent design
#### CONS ####

Controls can be annoying since when you tap outside of the puzzle frame, you will exit the puzzle.
Unclear hints
No tutorial, might have been come in handy for some people
Summary:
This game has a great potential between it's price tag and it's possibilities.
There is no replay-value in this game of course, i wanted to rule that out here.
The game has a bunch of achievements and trading cards intergration which will make everything even better for it's small price tag ( 1.99 ) .

I had some great fun! Thanks !

PS: We got a free copy of this game provided by the developers

reviewText:
This is a short puzzle collection, not an adventure.

The room with the hare in the cage allows access to a number of different puzzles. These have to be solved in order, and after an hour or so the hare is free. What looks like a game for kids is in actuality a diverse combinaton of puzzles which need to be solved by logic, trial and error, or sheer luck (e.g. the fish tank magnet), and that range from very easy to very difficult (the forum has a very useful post on the swap puzzle, thanks to graewynd). There's also a fair amount of clicking around to even find the next active puzzle to solve. There is no backstory to speak of, and no reward for completing it.

To sum it up: it is rather short and rather annoying (what is the next puzzle? and the difficulty fluctuations), and not worth your time. Get Puzzle Agent instead, it is a much better game in every respect.

P.S.: I got this game in two bundles and have a key left over, if you want to try it out anyway, leave a reply.

reviewText: I don't think it's bragging to say I finished this game in 1.5 hours.  I'm sure some people will do it on their first try in less time than that.  If you know what you're getting for your <$2, it's really good.  Its crisp artwork and responsive puzzles are just right for a short puzzler.  It isn't really a hidden object game in any traditional sense, in that you never have a list of objects to find in a cluttered scene.  It is way more consistent with mobile games of the room escape genre, except there's just one room populated by a few longer puzzles of the traditional varieties: towers of Hanoi, jigsaw, and sliding block games, plus a chess puzzle that isn't entirely clear but not too hard to work out if you know how chess pieces move.  I really wish there were more rooms.

reviewText: I want to start by warning that this game is VERY short.  It is still well made, and I believe it is worth the price. reviewText:
I found this game to be exactly as described on the tin. A mix of escape the room and find the item. A couple of medium difficulty puzzles, but nothing too new or hard for a fan of such games to work out. Well animated and decent music. Unlike some point and clicks the items you find have a logical use and I didn't need to use a herring on a big tree.

The one downside I would say is that having completed the game, my play time is 46 minutes. This may be increased by others as I was familiar with all of the puzzles and how they work, but I wouldn't see anyone getting more than a couple of hours out of this.

The downside mentioned is counteracted, of course, by the price. I bought it on sale for £0.95 and I certainly got more enjoyment out of it then a cup of tea I could buy with that change.

Overall, I would recommend this to those who enjoy escape the room games, but it is nothing too special or grand. I hope that the developers will put the time in to create a longer title of a similar vein.

reviewText:
Not bad game, but it feels to short, limited and uninspired to really recommend. The game takes place in only single location and doesn't really have any story at all. All you are doing is solving puzzle games that give you items to be used in other puzzles. The puzzle minigames themshelves are well done, but also feel completly arbitary, there is no rhyme or reason to what items they provide you with. The whole theme of freeing that rabbit isn't integrated into the flow of puzzle solving at all.

The game also doesn't do a great job at explaining itself, it just throws you into a room with no explanation. Clicking on things lacks audible feedback, so you often wonder if the game is broken and ignoring you clicks or if you are doing something wrong. I also had a technical issue where the game wouldn't play any sound at all and clicking the sound-icon didn't do anything to reenabling it, after a few restarts that however solve itself.

Aside from the lack of story, the weakest part in this game is the music, its not very good and also very erradic, sometimes you don't have any music for a while, then it comes back again. There is also a radio-puzzles where the music plays right over the sounds coming out of the radio, as it turns out the puzzle doesn't depend on the sound, but having those playing at the same time was irretating nontheless.

Overall its an ok game, but it's less then an hour long and the lack of any kind of story is really holding it back.

reviewText:
I didn't really dislike this game. It was a short yet interesting sequence of puzzles - some very easy, some others a little bit more difficult but never impossible to solve on your own - that costed me less than one Euro, gave me 4 cards to resell, kept me entertained for one hour and gave me achievements.
Why am I red-flagging it, then? Why am I not recommending it?
Because of the achievements design. Yes, a fairly good game that otherwise would get a solid 7/10 is mercilessy flagged as a fail, and all because of some minor/secondary elements like the achievements.
But the way they were implemented is so ill-chosen... so WRONG... that I have no choice but doing that.

Practices and decisions like this one, while certainly original and probably made in good faith, have to be killed before they grow adults.

Basically, the game has one achievement for each puzzle in the game. You solve the puzzle, you get the achievement. Easy  peasy. You can also skip a puzzle if you just can't solve it. Why, thanks dev. I like to have fun to play games and if I stop having fun trying (and inexorably failing) to beat a puzzle\level\enemy I like to be able to skip the whole thing in order to keep doing other things that I like more. So when I bumped into what I consider the most difficult puzzle of this game and after I tried (and inexorably failed) to beat it for 35 minutes... I decided to skip it.
I won't get the achevement for this
recommended: I thought.\nOnly it revealed to be a BIG issue.\nBecause if you skip one game you are marked A CHEATER and
voteText:
you are not able to get ANY other achievement. Never again. Even if you restart the game. Even if you reinstall the game. I don't even.
I'm not an achievement hunter but I like to mantain my average game completion rate constant and getting a 5/17 was very different than the 16/17 I thought I would get... so I kept trying and trying and trying... and failing and failing... and swearing... and eventually I succeded but I stopped enjoying the game as a whole.

English is not my first language and maybe I can't properly explain HOW ATROCIOUS I think this design choice is. It does not make sense in ANY way you try to consider it.
- I skip ONE puzzle out of 14 and I am a cheater? Are you kidding me?
- I skip one puzzle but I don't get achievements for puzzles that I don't skip? What?
- Your explanation for all of this cr*p is that you worked hard for months and you don't want players to rush to the end? This is the biggest bul**hit of them all. Just implement a different kind of achievements then. Or don't implement a UI skip button but some more hidden I-have-to-manually-edit-the-savegame way to skip the puzzles instead
helpfulPercent: making who does that an ACTUAL cheater.\nOr maybe you can just stop trying and NOT implementing achievements next time. It's a win-win

reviewText:
Hare In The Hat is a nice and short puzzle game. You solve puzzles that unlock compartments in objects and reveal items used to solve further puzzles. I would liken it to The Room, in terms of its core gameplay. The only problem is that it is far shorter and costs more than The Room. When I say that the Hare In The Hat is short, I mean that it will only take you roughly a single hour to complete the entire game, without any walkthrough or knowledge of what you have to do. On top of that, more than half of that time will be spent on one single puzzle - the sliding puzzle.

The achievements all follow linear progression... except for one, which has a *really* strange twist. One of the achievements you *have* to obtain last if you want 100% completion. It marks your account as a cheater, and from that point on you will *never* be able to get the other achievements, even after completely reinstalling the game! I have over 1,000 games in my library, and have *never* seen this in any other game. I am *not* a fan of this strange decision!

This game was initially made for iPhone, as is evident in the screenshot which is randomly included at the end of the trailer video. Simply porting a game from iPhone to Steam and charging $2 for it is a bit much. They didn't even do a good job with the port. The only option is full-screen, which renders strangely on my laptop. It *is* possible to change the resolution by piping through a launch command, but if this functionality is available... why couldn't they add an option *in-game*?

In summary, Hare In The Hat is a fun game, but considering how short it is, it is really not worth the price. Be *vary* wary of this game if you are a completionist! I got it as part of a bundle, and if you are lucky enough to, it's well worth giving a shot. If you are looking for a standalone puzzle game however, I'd have to recommend The Room instead.

There is a post about the 'Cheater' achievement over at http://steamcommunity.com/app/359810/discussions/0/487870763300646350/. Having read it I have serious doubts as to the integrity of the intentions of the developers of Hare In The Hat. If you cheated once and spit on my efforts on making this game
date: I see no reason to make anything for you. No game reset should clean it. If you don't like it - don't cheat... That's my game and if you don't like my rules - get you refund and get out" - Nomad (a developer)\n\n*Purely* based on Nomad's comments in that thread I am not only giving Hare In The Hat a negative review
recommended: but actively recommend that no-one gives these developers any money. Treating paying customers like that is deplorable."

reviewText:
I don't think I've ever had such a quick turnaround from the time I got a game, installed it, played it, completed it, and had a review written up for it, but that's the kind of game Hare in the Hat is - it shows up, does what it means to do, then leaves with a silent little bow and a tip of its cap, leaving us satisfyingly entertained before it has a chance to outstay its welcome.

We're given a few lines of story about how a wicked magician holds his performing hare captive, then we're thrown onto a single static screen of a room filled with lots of objects to interact with. Clicking on an object will zoom in and allow us to inspect the scene further, sometimes we'll be able to interact with something in a very limited way, sometimes not, until we find the right item to use on it later, but it's up to us to figure out how to gradually peel away the layers of puzzles presented to us and eventually release the poor, iddle-widdle bunny-wunny.

I really like how open this is. That we can examine everything and try to figure out for ourselves what our actions should be, rather than have a completely linear, signposted experience. Though I can also see that being a major issue for some people's progression as they'll click furiously around everything they can see, all the while being completely oblivious as to what the next step to be carried out should be. But I guess that's all part of the intended challenge. Otherwise, while there are one or two puzzles that may confuse or frustrate, and they really could have explained some of them a little better (I totally fluked my way through the coin puzzle at the end), for the most part the majority of players should be able to find their way through the game without too much hassle.

The look of the game is all pretty pleasant, maybe even cute" in its own little way
date: though the music leaves a little to be desired
recommended: as it plays for a moment
voteText: then starts again a few minutes later just as suddenly as it went. But as with the visuals
helpfulPercent: it's a nice enough little piano ditty carrying us through the game that
votesTotal: has its own little charms to it that are hard to dislike.\n\nAside from a few minor bumps along the road of progression
commentsCount: maybe an hour or so for most
column18: will take you longer to farm for trading cards than to actually complete. But it's a nice
column21: cheap little number that just about any puzzle fan should be able to enjoy."
